citation.article-title: Nonomuraea maritima sp. nov., isolated from coastal sediment
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Nonomuraea maritima sp. nov.
Nonomuraea maritima (ma.ri′ti.ma. L. fem. adj. maritima of the sea, marine, inhabiting marine environments).
Forms extensively branched, light yellow to brown substrate mycelia on ISP 2, ISP 5, Czapek’s and nutrient agars, and white substrate mycelia on ISP 3 and ISP 4 agars.
Abundant white aerial hyphae are formed on ISP 2, ISP 3 and ISP 4 agars.
No soluble pigments are produced on tyrosine agar (ISP 7).
Spiral spore chains composed of smooth to rough spores are observed on the aerial mycelium.
The temperature range for growth is 10–37 °C.
Positive for catalase and weakly positive for nitrate reduction.
Negative for urease, allantoin hydrolysis, gelatin liquefaction, starch hydrolysis, H2S production and guanine degradation.
The diagnostic amino acid of the peptidoglycan is meso-diaminopimelic acid.
Cell hydrolysates contain galactose, glucose, madurose, mannose and ribose.

Polar lipids include diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylmethylethanolamine, hydroxyphosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylinositol and phospholipids of unknown structure containing glucosamine.
The predominant menaquinone is MK-9(H4), with minor amounts of MK-9(H2), MK-9(H0) and MK-9(H6).
The fatty acids mainly comprise iso-C16 : 0, C17 : 1ω6c, iso-C16 : 1 G, 10-methyl C17 : 0 and iso-C15 : 0.
Additional phenotypic properties are shown in Table 1.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 70.1 mol%.
The type strain, FXJ7.203T ( = CGMCC 4.5681T = NBRC 106687T), was isolated from a coastal sediment sample.
